VS shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless PPD, its affiliates, directors, officers and employees thereof for any and all damages, costs, expenses and other liabilities, including reasonable attorney's fees and court costs, incurred by any such party as a result of any claim, action or proceeding by a third party (a "Third Party Claim") arising from VS's negligence, intentional misconduct, or breach of this Agreement.

PPD shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless VS, its directors, officers and employees thereof for any and all damages, costs, expenses and other liabilities, including reasonable attorney's fees and court costs, incurred by any such party as a result of any Third Party Claim arising from PPD's negligence, intentional misconduct, or breach of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text:
VS shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless PPD, its affiliates, directors, officers and employees thereof for any and all damages, costs, expenses and other liabilities incurred by any such party as a result of any claim, action or proceeding by a third party (a "Third Party Claim") arising from VS's intentional misconduct, or breach of this Agreement.

PPD shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless VS, its directors, officers and employees thereof for any and all damages, costs, expenses and other liabilities incurred by any such party as a result of any Third Party Claim arising from PPD's intentional misconduct, or breach of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'negligence' from the indemnification clauses, the contract fails to protect the parties from liabilities arising from their own negligence. Delaware law generally allows parties to contractually allocate risk, including indemnifying against one's own negligence under certain circumstances. Omitting indemnification for negligence significantly reduces protection, creating a situation where a party harmed by another's negligence may have limited recourse under this contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Delaware law regarding indemnification and limitations on liability

NOTWITHSTANDING ANYTHING TO THE CONTRARY CONTAINED IN THIS AGREEMENT, NEITHER PARTY SHALL BE LIABLE TO THE OTHER PARTY FOR INCIDENTAL, INDIRECT, CONSEQUENTIAL OR SPECIAL DAMAGES OR FOR ANY DAMAGES ARISING OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH ANY LOSS OF PROFIT, INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE OR LOSS OF BUSINESS OR ANTICIPATORY PROFITS, EVEN IF A PARTY OR ITS AFFILIATES HAVE BEEN APPRISED OF THE LIKELIHOOD OF SUCH DAMAGES OCCURRING, IN EACH CASE ARISING IN CONNECTION WITH ANY DEFAULT OR BREACH OF OBLIGATIONS UNDER THIS AGREEMENT OR ANY ATTACHMENTS HERETO.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'Gross Negligence' from the list of exceptions to the limitation of liability, the contract now limits a party's liability even for grossly negligent actions. This contradicts the general principle that parties should be responsible for the extreme forms of negligence. Delaware courts are less likely to enforce limitations on liability for gross negligence, as it borders on willful misconduct. This change introduces legal risk by weakening the accountability for severe lapses in care.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Delaware law regarding limitations on liability and gross negligence

perturbation.changed_text: THE WARRANTIES PROVIDED IN SECTION 8 AND ANY WORK ORDER ARE IN LIEU OF ALL OTHER CONDITIONS OR WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, WHETHER ARISING BY STATUTE, COURSE OF DEALING OR PERFORMANCE, CUSTOM, USAGE IN THE TRADE OR PROFESSION OR OTHERWISE, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO, FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE, AND ARE IN LIEU OF ALL OTHER OBLIGATIONS RELATING TO THE QUALITY OR ADEQUACY OF THE SERVICES IMPOSED BY LAW, ALL OF WHICH ARE EXPRESSLY DISCLAIMED TO THE EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'merchantability' from the disclaimer of warranties, the contract opens itself to implied warranty claims, particularly if the service is akin to a product. The Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), which Delaware has adopted, implies a warranty of merchantability in many transactions. Omitting the disclaimer makes it more likely that VS could be held liable if its services do not meet a basic standard of quality in the relevant industry.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Delaware's adoption of the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) and implied warranty of merchantability
